grounding: Chronic respiratory failure is a common, important complication of many types of neuromuscular and chest wall disorders. While the pathophysiology of each disease may be different, these disorders can variably affect all muscles involved in breathing, including inspiratory, expiratory, and bulbar muscles, ultimately leading to chronic respiratory failure and hypoventilation. The use of home assisted ventilation through noninvasive interfaces aims to improve the symptoms of hypoventilation, improve sleep quality, and, when possible, improve mortality. An increasing variety of interfaces has allowed for improved comfort and compliance. In a minority of scenarios, noninvasive ventilation is either not appropriate or no longer effective due to disease progression, and a transition to tracheal ventilation should be considered.
generated_text: Chronic neuromuscular respiratory failure is a debilitating condition characterized by the progressive weakening of respiratory muscles, leading to insufficient ventilation and gas exchange. Home assisted ventilation, particularly noninvasive ventilation (NIV), has emerged as a pivotal intervention in managing this condition. This approach offers significant benefits, including improved quality of life, reduced hospitalizations, and enhanced survival rates. Recent advancements in ventilatory technology and patient monitoring have further optimized the efficacy of home-based care. This review explores the pathophysiology of chronic neuromuscular respiratory failure, the role of NIV in home settings, and the latest innovations in ventilatory support. Emphasis is placed on patient selection, adherence, and the impact of personalized care strategies on clinical outcomes.
